importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication reflects the most current assessment of UK security threats as of mid-October 2025, highlighting the ongoing evolution of state and terrorist threats in the post-9/11 era.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article focuses on developments over the last year, particularly a 35% rise in state-sponsored suspects investigated by MI5, signaling a growing trend in espionage and sabotage operations.

keyTakeAways: MI5 has observed a 35% increase in the number of individuals investigated for state threat activity in the UK over the past year.
The primary state actors identified are Russia, China, and Iran, with over 20 potentially lethal Iran-backed plots reported in the last year.
Russian threats include arson, sabotage, and targeted intelligence gathering, often involving proxies that may not receive direct payment.

Recent espionage case: Orlin Roussev, a Bulgarian national, led a British-based Russian spy ring in 2024, sentenced to nearly 11 years in prison for surveillance of journalists, dissidents, and Ukrainian soldiers.
MI5 warns that artificial intelligence is being exploited by terrorists for propaganda, weapons research, and reconnaissance, though AI also enables better threat detection.
The combination of state-sponsored espionage and terrorist threats — including Islamist, extreme right-wing, and mentally disturbed actors — marks a 'new era' in UK security.

summaryOfNewsArticle: MI5 chief Ken McCallum warns that the UK is entering a 'new era' of national security threats, marked by a 35% rise in investigations into state-sponsored espionage over the past year. The primary threats come from Russian, Chinese, and Iranian state actors, including over 20 potentially lethal Iran-backed plots and Russian-linked arson and surveillance operations. A recent case involving Bulgarian nationals accused of running a British-based Russian spy ring underscores the growing presence of foreign intelligence operations in the UK. McCallum also highlights the emerging use of artificial intelligence by terrorists for propaganda and weapons research, while cautioning against overhyping its dangers. The article emphasizes the convergence of state-sponsored threats and extremist ideologies, such as those linked to ISIS and far-right extremism, as a major challenge to UK security.
title: ‘A new era’: UK facing rising threats from state actors as well as terrorists, says MI5 chief
